channel.title: Comments on: Mark making and early writing with young children, with help from Fleetwood Mac, Jean Michel Jarre and Captain Pugwash!
channel.description: Supporting children's language, communication and learning

item.title: By: Michael Jones
item.dc:creator: Michael Jones
item.description: Thanks Tim!!! An amp that goes up to 12?'why not buy a bigger amp?' ''Because this one goes up to 12' Does that make you the David St Hubbins of your band? Great to hear from you! Michael
item.content:encoded:
Thanks Tim!!!
An amp that goes up to 12?’why not buy a bigger amp?’ ”Because this one goes up to 12′
Does that make you the David St Hubbins of your band?
Great to hear from you!
Michael

item.title: By: Tim Dunkerley
item.dc:creator: Tim Dunkerley
item.description: Hey Michael I point you in the direction of a vid on youtube with, One Love (The Stone Roses) Sung in the voice of Captain Pugwash. Priceless. PS I have (really) just bought and amp and it goes to 12 Tim
item.content:encoded:
Hey Michael I point you in the direction of a vid on youtube with, One Love (The Stone Roses) Sung in the voice of Captain Pugwash. Priceless.
PS I have (really) just bought and amp and it goes to 12
Tim

item.title: By: Michael Jones
item.dc:creator: Michael Jones
item.description: Yes indeed. I've come in for quite a bit of stick about encouraging children to move to 'rock and pop' when really we should be 'inculcating' a love of 'classical' music. Hmmm... how to respond? I know that staff in Steiner schools have been using this approach since the schools were founded. However... (minefield approaching!!) Didn't Coleridge and friends enjoy the odd puff of laudanum? After you have visited the local 'Kubla Khan Coleridge Experience Tea Rooms' you may be whistling 'Xanadu' by Dave Dee, Dozy, Beaky, Mick & Titch (try moving to that!!!!)
item.content:encoded:
Yes indeed. I’ve come in for quite a bit of stick about encouraging children to move to ‘rock and pop’ when really we should be ‘inculcating’ a love of ‘classical’ music. Hmmm… how to respond? I know that staff in Steiner schools have been using this approach since the schools were founded. However… (minefield approaching!!)
Didn’t Coleridge and friends enjoy the odd puff of laudanum? After you have visited the local ‘Kubla Khan Coleridge Experience Tea Rooms’ you may be whistling ‘Xanadu’ by Dave Dee, Dozy, Beaky, Mick & Titch (try moving to that!!!!)

item.title: By: simon marley
item.dc:creator: simon marley
item.description:
Write Dance sounds well worth trying. I saw the value of movement and music and language learning with 'Take 10'video materials designed to help children learn foreign languages.
Going on a walk starting at Coleridge's cottage in Nether Stowey, Somerset on Sunday. Will be whistling 'Albatross' along the way.
item.content:encoded:
Write Dance sounds well worth trying. I saw the value of movement and music and language learning with ‘Take 10’video materials designed to help children learn foreign languages.

Going on a walk starting at Coleridge’s cottage in Nether Stowey, Somerset on Sunday. Will be whistling ‘Albatross’ along the way.

item.title: By: Michael Jones
item.dc:creator: Michael Jones
item.description:
Hi Sue I should point out that the Write Dance programme is a brilliant idea, and I highly recommend that teachers invest in it. The point I'm making in the post is that some adults and children don't instantly 'get into' the music or language, while others do, so they should consider adapting it to suit the children they are working with.
You can find out more by visiting writedancetraining.com Thanks for your kind comments! Keep smiling, man. Michael
item.content:encoded:
Hi Sue
I should point out that the Write Dance programme is a brilliant idea, and I highly recommend that teachers invest in it. The point I’m making in the post is that some adults and children don’t instantly ‘get into’ the music or language, while others do, so they should consider adapting it to suit the children they are working with.

You can find out more by visiting writedancetraining.com
Thanks for your kind comments! Keep smiling, man.
Michael

item.title: By: Michael Jones
item.dc:creator: Michael Jones
item.content:encoded:
‘This amp is specially designed to be extra loud, so it can be turned up to 11’
‘Why not just buy a bigger amp?’
‘Because this one goes up to 11’ it’s logical….
Seriously Mine, please read my reply to Sue Thomas about the value of Write Dance. It’s a great scheme, but like any approach in education, teachers should feel free to adapt a resource to meet the needs of the children they are working with.

item.title: By: Mine Conkbayir
item.dc:creator: Mine Conkbayir
item.description: Love the Spinal Tap reference! Another great piece which is easy to put to practical use! Thanks Michael : )
item.content:encoded: Love the Spinal Tap reference! Another great piece which is easy to put to practical use! Thanks Michael : )

item.title: By: Sue Thomas
item.dc:creator: Sue Thomas
item.description: This is so true Michael, the soprano voice, lyrics and music in Write Dance made us all want to run away and 'wave' goodbye for ever! Who can forget the memorable ditty, 'My hill is over there, your hill is over here'?? Thank once again for taking the time to write these great blogs - they are full of really interesting stuff and always make me smile.
item.content:encoded:
This is so true Michael, the soprano voice, lyrics and music in Write Dance made us all want to run away and ‘wave’ goodbye for ever! Who can forget the memorable ditty, ‘My hill is over there, your hill is over here’??
Thank once again for taking the time to write these great blogs – they are full of really interesting stuff and always make me smile.
